Consider the principles of shadow formation and how they are affected by the position of the light source.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the size of the object, the distance between the object and the light source, and the distance between the object and the surface on which the shadow falls.
When the light source moves backwards, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
As the light source moves further away, the shadow becomes smaller.
The shadow will also shift position, moving in the opposite direction towards the objects.

As the light source moves backwards, shadow A will become smaller and move closer to the birdcage.
Shadow B is the shadow of the box.

Shadow C will become smaller and move closer to the lamp.
